Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This is easily one of the worst courses Ive ever taken at Yale, if not THE worst one. I would go as so far as to say that I prefer gen chem lab with Dr. G over this course. The lab manuals are poorly writtenits almost a free-flow of thoughts rather than a well-organized manual of procedures/insights. They often have pertinent information given at the end/briefly mentioned once. However, this is not the worst of it. You really dont get any contact with the professors (and when you do, they just refer you to the TF), although they seem cool, if not indifferent. The TFs are mostly first-years who are eager to bring you down, belittle your questions, have as little contact with you as possible, or straight-up have no idea what the lab information is (an answer of Hmm, I dont know. What youre saying makes sense but also I dont know. is not uncommon). My own TF was pretty good, but still a bit frustrating to see it collectively. They dont have a set of rubrics or guidelines from the professors, so theyre also mostly just reaizing/making up information as you go through the lab. This translates to gradingthere are no formal rubrics. The exams are the WORSTinstead of using to really learn a concept, you have a series of three very, very rushed experiments that you just finish and do for the sake of the graders joy in destroying you. You dont get time to think, which is ironic but not surprising from this class. The professor said the exams are not meant to be cruel but LOL you really dont learn much about physics at all. If anything, I guess you learn more about how to use LoggerPro? Literally will retain nothing from this course. The exams are really not conducive to reinforcing any of the knowledge either. But if you have to take it, you do. Its mostly pointless concepts you can just understandthat are weirdly made difficult and convoluted.
How to follow a rubric.
How to carry out physics experiments.
To flip a coin 500 times
How to do basic physics experiments
This class somewhat reinforced lecture topics.
A tangible approach to concepts from the first half of the intro to physics sequence at Yale.

I really liked how this course was shaped, and I truly believe that the way it has been constructed helps students focus on 'learning' than just blindly chasing grades. You get to acquire some intuitions on law of physics rather than just relying on equations.
The class makes you think critically about how to test theoretical physics concepts in the real world which is cool.
I learned the setup of extremely basic kinematic experiments, the physical processes that drive/govern them, and how to deal with errors and uncertainties in calculations.
I learned how to calculate uncertainties in measurements. I also learned how to record data properly and use LoggerPro.
Developed skills necessary to conduct well thought out experiments based on my own logic and thought process
We did a lot of computer aided graphical analysis through LoggerPro and did experiments involving projectile motion, rotational concepts, kinematics, energy, torque, and other basic physics concepts.
General applications of mechanical physics
I took my first college lab! I learned how to use a bunch of cool lab equipment.
More knowledge of physics concepts learned in class, critical thinking about physics problems, use of Logger Pro and other lab tools
This lab reinforced concepts I had learned in PHYS 180 last year.
I learned how to conduct basic physics experiments in the laboratory, and also gained some knowledge of statistical processes to analyze agreements between measurements.
There a lot of cool ways to see physics in actions! This taught us a few and really helped me facilitate an understanding of what was going on in class.
Physics laboratory techniques, understanding of uncertainty and systematic errors
How to conduct simple experiments in a lab setting and effectively analyze results.
Basic lab skills (ie how to use LoggerPro and all of the associated devices, how to design a simple procedure to test a variable)
reinforced physics concepts from lecture such as rotational motion.
I learned more about concepts in physics by performing hands-on experiments. I also learned about uncertainties. A LOT about uncertainties. Certainly more than I needed to.
I think that they physics lab gave me a better understanding of the concepts that I was learning in Physics 180. I enjoyed the labs and they helped my see real world applications of the concepts.
I learned how different physics concepts worked.
How to use LoggerPro to measure various physical quantities, and how to create and execute experiments to illustrate certain physics concepts.
I did not want to take this course but had to because of pre-med requirement
I learned how to propagate error calculations and use Logger Pro
I developed the necessary skills I will need to think critically in a laboratory setting.
The course was a great opportunity to apply the concepts learned in lecture. I became better at designing experiments and gained a deeper understanding of concepts like torque and kinematics.
Literally nothing. I essentially just learned how to calculate uncertainties using an excel spreadsheet.
The main insight I gained from the class was carrying error through calculations.

I gained a deeper understanding of how the topics we learn in lecture appear in real-life, and the labs were useful in understanding many real world phenomena. One of the goals of this class is to become comfortable with uncertainties: while I am not completely comfortable with them yet, the labs introduced me to them and I feel I made progress over the semester.
I learned how to use logger pro and about basic experimental physics techniques such as recording the motion of objects.
I learned about physics and how to make measurements of physics in the natural world. I learned how to use a equipment like a motion sensor and loggerPro.
Not much beyond common sense and what I had already learned in physics.
I learned very little.
Practical experience with physics labs
It is good to see all the physics concepts in action.
How to calculate uncertainties, how to analyze experiments for errors, how to use LoggerPro, basic physics relationships like terminal velocity, measuring gravity, conservation of energy, etc.
I learned basic lab skills in relation to physics.
I learned nothing in this useless course
I learned about basic phenomena in physics that we were learning in lecture.
I developed skills with operating Logger Pro.
Reading from instructions and doing what they tell you to do.
Basic physics lab skills
How to maneuver physics lab equipment. How to demonstrate physics concepts with this equipment.
We learned knowledge that accompanied the paired lecture as well as seeing first hand how properties of physics work.
Application and hands-on experience of physics problems.
I learned various physics laboratory skills.

I was able to apply theoretical concepts of physics to real-life lab situations. I also learned how to do experiments under pressure. Furthermore, I learned the importance of keeping organized lab notes.
Use physics concepts in real-world application
I learned how to use Logger Pro
Using lab equipment; lab safety; teamwork and cooperation; working under pressure
I didn't really get anything out of this course other than learning that labs suck.
Uncertainties, error propagation, basic measuring of physical parameters, lots of logger pro

I learned how to successfully complete a physics lab in the time allotted. The lab supplemented concepts learned in class. I also learned how to use many different apparati that had previously been foreign to me.
How to perform basic physics labs.
I learned physics laboratory techniques, which I will likely never use again beyond this course, since I'm pre-med. I also learned a lot about uncertainties in experimentation.
I learned how to operate LoggerPro, and sort of learned how to design a physics experiment.
I learned basic lab and error analysis skills. The lab also helped me review physics basics.
I learned basic physics laboratory skills, especially how to use loggerpro and determine the uncertainty of my measurements.
I learned how to complete and present a lab by myself. I also practiced troubleshooting.
How to find sources of error and the importance of uncertainty
I learned how to use physics equipment in a controlled setting.
I learned how to demonstrate physical properties of the world through simple experiments and data collection methods.

I learned about basic techniques in physics labs (e.g. how to conduct and design physics experiments including determining spring constants, determining a value of g, etc). I also learned a great deal about how to include uncertainties in measurements and propagate them throughout calculations.
I learned how to write a basic lab report and how to conduct an experiment. I learned how to check my work and uncertainties.
The hands-on aspect of this lab gives you some good intuition for the physical concepts you learn in class.
I learned how to work in a formal lab setting
Mechanics lab procedures and techniques.
I learned how to use logger pro.
General physics lab procedures like spring constants and balls dropping
This class allows you to practice understanding scientific experimentation and furthers your understanding of concepts in physics.
None
General laboratory skills

I gained an understanding of several basic techniques used in a basic physics setting, such as video analysis, as well as an increased understanding of both attempting to minimize uncertainties and error in measurements and accounting for the remaining uncertainties as a tangible number.
physics labs like simple harmonic motion, momentum, etc.
Learned how to do different physics labs.
I better understood the methods utilized in a lab setting.
Basic physics lab concepts, importance of uncertainty in experimentation (and how to account for it)
I learned about the tools for running physics experiments and saw some physics concepts in the real world through the experiments.
General physics topics
None
This lab course is great! I learned so much about physics concepts through hands on experience.
I learned how to apply physical concepts to understanding processes happening around me in the world today.
I do not think I developed any skills from this course.
I was able to put my physics knowledge into practice.

I learned how to set up a lab experiment, what kinds of errors to test for, what kinds of methods can answer different questions, and some insights that helped with physics 170, which I was also taking at the time.
I followed directions to complete lab experiments related to themes studied in Physics 180.
H O R R I B L E CLASS
Er not a lot...i learned how to take the course, like how to interpret and follow their directions, better. That could be applicable outside of the class.
I leaned a lot about writing up experimental summaries and various physical properties and how to measure them.

Improved ability to complete practical physics experiments and to think critically about such physics experiments. Applying theoretical concepts learned in lecture built a different type of understanding and appreciation for physics.
I learned about basic physic concepts and about uncertainty and how to analyze scientific data.
None really
relevant information about measurement uncertainty and certain physics principles
I learned how to conduct and evaluate the results of lab investigations.

It was fun to be able to see physics principles being demonstrated in real life; you learn how to keep a lab notebook organized and how to write concisely when turning in lab reports. It was a relatively painless physics lab course, and as long as you explain and identify errors, then you will not be docked points, which is good, because a lot of error can come about even if you're not careful.
too much tedious work, too much weight given to final experiments conducted in too little time
Look at previous feedback and actually make changes based on it
The grading was wildly inconsistent so I had no idea what was expected of me each week.
Very comprehensive lab handouts, feel like I learned a lot.
Make it worth 0.75 credits

Strengths: lab instructions and Dr. Baker's engagement with the course
Weakness: Too much variation in grading style of the TAs.

Working in partners was not the best, please make it so that a student can do the lab themselves. The final was also really hard (much harder than the midterm) because of time constraints and just overall difficulty of the concepts being tested. The final should more closely mimic what we've had to do all semester with the amount of time we've had.
Many of the labs are very tedious, I feel like much of the content can be covered in a textbook and doesn't really necessitate hands-on learning.

Final and midterm could be improved. I do not think it really goes align with the whole course to be so strict with time- some people just need more time to  think, but to be penalized because of it- is a great contradiction.

Strengths:  It's really cool to be able to see all these really theoretical concepts that you have learned about actually work in real life.
Weaknesses:  The order of the labs doesn't really make sense.  Our first lab was simple harmonic motion, which we didn't learn about in physics lecture until closer to the end of the semester.

Strengths: obviously hands on as a lab course
Weakness: not many of the experiments felt fun or relevant to us learning. Not the best way to communicate this material in terms of engagement

The practical midterm and final were too rushed and did not reflect our learning in the course well at all. I would recommend allowing more time if doing a practical final or doing away with the practical final. Otherwise, the labs were good, and the course was run well. I feel that the lab reports were of very fair length and content for a half credit lab course.

Very straightforward laboratory experiments (strength). Weakness would be the professors absence. Only saw him once in the beginning of the semester and never again. Perhaps the professor could offer suggestions in experiments for a short pre lab lecture to push students in the right direction or explain elusive topics.

The course was actually pretty enjoyable and a relatively good experience in lab until the final practical. There was far too much stress packed into 3 hours and there was not sufficient time to thoroughly complete all of the experiments in the 55 minutes allotted for each one.

This lab does a good job of getting students familiar with important lab concepts such as error and uncertainty. Also, the rotation labs helped me understand torque and angular momentum better through hands-on demonstrations.

Strengths= grading guidelines were clearly stated and questions were challenging but straightforward
Weaknesses= some labs were really tedious (radioactivity lab where we had to wait for an hour for something to decay)
This course is somewhat tedious and repetitive, but it is well organized, well run, and clearly laid out.
This class was very structured. As far as introductory lab courses go, it was a good course. The way that the final was structured could be improved.

Strengths are the practicallity of these labs and being able to fit them into just 3 hours. It would be improved with better lab manual things. If there were perhaps more images or maybe even videos such as those provided for orgo lab, that would be awesome.
Interesting lab, good TA, practical exams were different compared to other courses
The course instructor often did not know the labs inside out, which made it difficult to perform them in a timely manner.

I really liked the TF for my section, but upon talking to my classmates in other sections I discovered the grading for the course was very dependent on your TF. I think this could be improved by a more structured grading system.
The handouts were super thorough and helpful. The labs themselves were often times interesting. The midterm was fine (but rushed) and the final seemed completely unfair.

Strengths: in a few cases (especially rotational motion) is helpful in helping you understand topics covered in lecture (phys 180)
weaknesses: labs are incredibly boring and require strict attention to tiny details, neglecting conceptual understanding in many cases since you must focus on the exact number of decimal places to use in one part of an equation. Actual skills are really poorly taught. For example, you must learn uncertainty calculations, but instead of actually teaching them, they're just sprinkled in here and there and it's expected that you somehow uderstand them. Grading is arbitrary and feedback is almost nonexistent. The final is not even technically difficult, but the ridiculously short amount of time given per experiment means it is a very stressful time crunch. Overall just a very disappoitingly poorly organized course that amounts to a grand waste of time and lots of needless stress.

Strengths: This course provides a different way to learn about physics--namely, through hands-on work.

Weaknesses: The most significant weakness of this course is the lack of transparency in regards to how students are evaluated. Aside from the differences in how TA's evaluate work, there is not enough explicit information about what we are being graded on. In regards to the midterm, there was no rubric publicly provided to the students. Errors you made were not explained at all (at most a few words), leaving you with no idea as to how to improve. Also, the course packet, while detailed and mostly thorough, should be simplified, allowing students to focus on one key takeaway per lab instead of five. Furthermore, the wording of the course packet is confusing at times, leaving the students to batter their TAs with questions.

I don't think it really had any weaknesses, but I wouldn't say there was anything that stood out as a strength either. It covered a lot of information which was good. Overall it wasn't super remarkable.
Not much instruction in the conceptual part of the labs. You just had to read the course packet and come to class understanding it.

Some of the experiments are interesting and it can be exciting to get the results. Many helpful resources on the Canvas website, such as reference sheets, excel sheets.

Weaknesses: Some of the lab manuals are very poorly written, which result in a lot of confusion until your TA clears things up.

I though the course tried to make the content interesting, but honestly, there is little fun in doing uncertainty calculations 5 times. There are some labs such as the ones where we could spin around on a chair that seemed interesting, but others made us try to become another Galileo.
I wish these labs correlated more with what we are learning in class. Sometimes they did, but often I found myself coming across concepts we had only brushed by in class.
You learn how to use Logger Pro and do error calculations well, but the class is really boring and you don't get much out of it
It could be improved by making it clearer from the start how the lab report submissions would be graded. That was a bit ambiguous.

This class is very well organized and the workload is perfect for a lab class (I have never ever written this in a review before). The post-lab assignments are simple and the midterm and final are necessary. The experiments are also as fun as they can be, and they are informative. One weakness is that the final exam was unnecessarily difficult, such that it made me question whether I had learned anything during the semester. Also, students' overall experience of the course varies drastically depending on their TA's.

Strengths: Good packets, helpful TAs, nice professors
Weaknesses: Sometimes the experiments were a little too trivial... e.g. coin flipping.

For me one of the biggest weaknesses was the weekly reports. For literally every other science we write formal lab reports. I thought the summary and afterthoughts thing was well intentioned, but doesn't really hit the mark because all those who are taking the class and going into science will have to write formal reports, it doesn't make sense not to in this course.

Weakness: no standardized grading. The instructors NEED to fix this because this is not okay. I don't care what they say about 'normalizing the grades.' If all the students in one section are scoring near perfect, what exactly are you normalizing to?

It is 0.5 credits, which i find to be a disgrace. The workload for this, in terms of preparation and write-ups, should have been worth a full credit. It just took away from the course if I didn't feel that it was worth my time to put that much effort in for so little benefit. The material was actually interesting, though. Write-ups were a bit annoying because they were graded in a picky manner. Some labs felt unnecessary

While I found most of the experiments to be engaging and interesting, some seemed to be out of place with the course goals. That said, the experiments were well written and instructed. However, for a note on laboratory courses in general, I strongly believe that they should be worth one credit compared to the half credit that they are currently worth. Not only is the class three hours long (and for chemistry four hours), but also this course requires an equal amount of time outside of class compared to one credit courses, that results from laboratory reports and pre-laboratory reading.

While the labs were interesting, sometimes I felt they were leading us in a certain direction too directly, as if we knew exactly where we wanted to end up. This made the labs easier, but at the same time, made them feel more like a task or a chore rather than an experiment.

This course required very little critical thinking as they lay out all the laboratory procedures for you. Actually doing the experiments feels mindless as you are just following the procedure given to you and not doing any thinking of your own. The only concept that I felt was improved by taking this course was torque and angular momentum.
I think this course is well-organized to facilitate student learning. Having a clear schedule from the get-go, and all of the experiment instructions online in advance is excellent.
The labs were interesting, but I had a bad TF so the labs always dragged on because he didn't know what to do.

The experiments are boring, tedious, and an overall waste of time. Make the lab less about formalized lab reports and actually teach the students about the practical or real applications of what is discussed in the physics lecture courses. You can do well in this class by simply following basic instructions, no real learning.
The labs were a bit dry. They illustrated the concepts, but were boring.
Final was too long for the time given. Could be made shorter.
The actual labs are about as interesting as physics labs can be, but there is a lot of busywork and very menial tasks that need to be described or completed.

As an introductory course there is limited flexibility, but I thought that the course focused much more on picky details than big picture stuff. I was disappointed with how poorly this lab class aligned with PHYS 170 (especially the labs on torque and rotation). I spent so much time rewriting all my lab notes because if I didn't I would lose many points. So much time was spent calculating uncertainties instead of exploring physics. So many cool things could be done with this course... but instead it is a weekly pain, especially if you have a nitpicky TA. There is WAY too much variability based on TAs, especially with regard to insight points.
The uncertainty lab (with dice) and the radioactive decay lab should be replaced because they were unnecessarily long ways of explaining uncertainty and decay properties.
Okay course overall. The labs weren't that interesting, but the level of work was low.

This course might be improved by informing students exactly how to succeed on the midterm and final practical exams. The exams themselves seemed fair, but I felt blind going into the exams as to what to expect and how to prepare.
make this course less useless
This wasn't a very engaging class. I think the best way that it could be improved is if there was more feedback given on lab reports and midterms/exams.
A lot of this lab was time-filling lab work that didn't actually inform our understanding of physical laws, like when we spent hours simply doing uncertainty calculations by hand.

The course doesn't have too many strengths and weaknesses.  Its a simple lab that is probably pretty similar wherever you go.  Its a lot better than any chemistry lab and pretty low-stress.  I learned some good skills like error propogation

Overly difficult to do well on lab reports and they comprise a majority of the overall grade. It seems like our evaluation has nothing to do with understanding of material nor how well we complete the experiment, rather how "interesting my post-lab write up was". The lab also did not match well with the material we learned in class.
The lab setup was great and the way lab partners were assigned was good too. The only thing that could be improved was a more detailed explanation of what the lab summary should include.
The expectations of the lab reports were unclear. A rubric would have been very helpful.

Strengths: It is organized.

Weaknesses: Sometimes it can be repetitive.

One weakness of this course is that it has a 0% correlation with PHYS 170, although the course is designed to be taken with 170/180. PHYS is not a light subject, and a lot of the labs in this course need knowledge prior to conducting the lab. For example, we did a lab on angular momentum and my teaching fellow was surprised to hear that my class hadn't touched on the topic before because she didn't think it was a topic that could be understood in the lab we were given and in the 3 hours we had to do it. Either make the class correspond to something that provides the background knowledge, or provide the knowledge in the class itself through lessons (not just through the summaries in the lab reports). This is imperative, especially if we are expected to showcase a full understanding of the material during the midterm and final exams.
The midterm and final are way too stressful
This class is very organized but also a lot of busy work. The quizzes were often unclear with very tedious wording and required outside knowledge of physics where lecture had not always yet provided.

Strengths: Practical exams are smart, if not somewhat stressful, idea; reinforces things I learn in lecture

Weaknesses: "Insight" section of lab reports seems nebulously defined at times; uncertainty calculations are terrible, though I'm grateful that they allow us to use a special spreadsheet to do them; 1-page report of labs is easy (which is nice) but not necessarily useful for learning (even the "insight" portion doesn't do much)

Strengths: my TA Hannah was really nice. Weaknesses: different TA's have very different grading styles and an A with one TA might be a B with another. The final exam was crazy -- I think it dropped my grade so much because I kept running out of time to do the stations. I felt like the final exam was impossible to prepare for since they expect you to do the experiments in 1/3 the amount of time we usually have in class. It's intimidating being like one of the only premeds in a class full of engineer and physics people. I also feel like I didn't learn anything concrete from this class-- it was just a lot of pain and suffering doing lab reports each week. I only learned how to use LoggerPro from this class and that's not a very helpful skill since I don't plan on taking any more physics lab classes after the spring.

Strengths: a good variety of labs that go along with what we learn in Physics 180 lecture
Weaknesses: midterm and final are done individually which is not something we practice from week to week so it is significantly harder and more nerve wracking; some of the labs are repetitive

Perhaps, have people practice a few times throughout the semester doing a one hour lab on their own so they know what it is like.

I honestly did not enjoy this course at all. I dreaded going to this class every week because I never found the labs interesting, useful, or good at teaching or reinforcing the concepts behind the experiments. I never felt like I learned anything from the experiments we were doing, and they often felt very trivial and pointless. There also wasn't a lot of feedback to improve our learning or correct us if we came to the wrong conclusions or didn't understand the concepts and the results fully. The weekly lab reports sometimes felt like busy work, and I didn't really learn much by doing them; additionally, the grading sometimes wasn't very clear, particularly relating to the "insight" section because the syllabus and all of the TAs weren't very clear on what exactly they were looking for. I also had a major problem with the ways that we were assessed in this class. While every week was structured as doing one experiment with a partner in a 3 hour block of time, the midterm was one experiment in one hour while the final was 3 experiments, each taking 55 minutes. The assessments were not reflective of how we learned the material and performed the experiments at all. The time constraint experienced during the assessments, since we only have one hour or less time for an experiment even though we have grown accustomed to having 3 hours per experiment, caused a lot of anxiety and stress that could have been avoided if the weekly labs reflected what we would be expected to do in the assessments. Overall, I think this course needs to change in a lot of ways.
Labs are not very clearly written, that don't take the estimated time, and you don't learn anything in them
Not super engaging or interesting, but super time-consuming or difficult either.

Strengths: relatively short 
Weaknesses: grading completely biased on which TA you have... try a rotating TA system like chemistry lab

Personally, I felt that the final was not a fair representative of the labs that was covered throughout the semester. I did not believe that the labs throughout the course prepared me for the final. Although the midterm was helpful in giving me an idea of how the final would be like, it would have been more be helpful to provide us with feedback on how to improve after the midterm for the final practical. The grading was very dependent on the TA, especially the "insight" portion of the lab report which my TA never provided clear feedback on how to improve on.

Strengths are that the weekly lab reports were a pretty reasonable length, and most labs take less than the allotted 3 hours so you could usually leave early. Weaknesses are that honestly the 5-minute weekly quizzes were harder than they needed to be, and that the final exam was a pretty ridiculous level of difficulty that was not at all represented by the labs throughout the semester.

The strengths were the instructors: they were helpful, kind, and invested in our success. The weaknesses was the content; the experiments were somewhat boring and I wasn't very interested in them (though, to be fair, I'm not very interested in physics).
The labs were very informative and structured, which is good. I think it could be improved by delving more into physics concepts rather than just looking at computer data.

The labs themselves are manageable, but the midterm/final was unnecessarily stressful not because they were hard experiments but because the 55 minute time limit did not seem to be enough for the experiments planned. I think there is also too much emphasis on finding uncertainties, and the grading can be kind of arbitrary depending on your TA (i.e. getting points taken off because our results did not agree within their uncertainties especially when this expectation was not made clear to us during the experiment).

Labs are extremely tedious and not really that interactive. They were all basically like following a laundry list of instructions. They are also pretty poorly written, so it is difficult to follow along without asking the TA for help. The material was not even that hard, but it was tedious to spend an entire 3 hours standing there, usually just waiting.
It covers a lot of basic physics principles but it can be quite boring and excessively tedious at times.

Some experiments were a bit tedious but I guess that is to be expected. I guess sometimes the instructions in the lab handouts werent super clear so you needed to ask your TA in order to actually know how to effectively do the experiment. I felt like sometimes I wasnt able to properly problem-solve on my own and just had to rely on my TA telling me what I should do.

The staff were very invested, but the labs were horrible! Even though the workload was fair, I did not feel like I learned much from doing the labs. They were very tedious, and it seemed like my TA wasn't even sure about the correct way to do things sometimes. Also, the final was the worst thing I have ever done, and ruined the fact that the labs at the end of the semester were kind of fun. That kind of time pressure makes no sense -- I understand making sure that we can apply the concepts and skills we learned, and that time shouldn't be unlimited, but it's outrageous to ask us to do it in an hour. It was so stressful and an unnecessarily horrible experience.

A strength of this course is that each lab is designed well and clearly thought out. A weakness is that the experience you have in lab and grading is largely dependent on TAs. I happened to have a good TA, who could explain confusing concepts in lab as they came up, but a lot of my friends in other sections fumbled through the labs without a clear idea of what they were doing. Also, the midterm and final experiments were just a poor gauge of our understanding throughout the semester, especially since we were so pressured for time throughout. An improvement would be to maybe design the midterm and final to be more similar to what we did throughout the semester, and make them count for less of our grade.
I love that this class met once a week so it was pretty low commitment level. However, if you missed a lab, it was difficult to schedule enough make up time without missing another lab.

It's a pretty solid course, the only thing I'd change is giving a rubric for the lab reports; for example, it's kind of unclear what they expect for the INSIGHT section, and the feedback I received was not very helpful and made the grading seem subjective.

Strengths - half-credit workload
Weaknesses - TF didn't give good advice, made it difficult to improve learning

The material was not very well connected to what I was learning in lecture (I was in PHYS 170) and the way lab reports were graded was really frustrating. My TA was also very unhelpful and I feel like he detracted from my experience.
The midterm and final are both really hard, the TAs do not grade uniformly from section to section
The course has a low workload and some of the labs aren't very challenging. As a result, you don't learn as much as you could.

I felt there was a large disconnect between the content we learned in 170 and the experiments done in lab. I never really understood the content of the lab even though I read the lab instructions. The people in 180 always seemed one step ahead.
I think the course overall is good, and the labs were interesting.  I did not think the lab practicals assessed learning. They just assessed how quickly you could do the labs.
Some experiments run over the 3 hour time

The strengths are that the pre-lab write-ups provide a wealth of information not only about the specific experiment that will be performed on a given day, but also an explanation of related physics concepts and of how the concepts relate to other areas of physics and to the real world. Also, students are kept in the loop through helpful, detailed emails/Canvas announcements and the teaching staff is readily accessible. The weaknesses are that a lot of any given student's experience relies on their specific TA, and that the final lab practical is very stressful. It accounts for such a hefty part of the final grade, but it is easy to make mistakes out of rushing or nerves due to the given environment. I don't necessarily think it is the best measure of how knowledgeable students are or how comfortable they are in a lab environment.
weakness: phys 180 students are much better prepared; some of the lab topics weren't even covered in phys 170
great prof, interesting experiments
These course is definitely tedious, but it is not very difficult.
No noticeable weaknesses, but more feedback on lab reports would be helpful

This course could be improved by making the guidelines for each lab very clear. I found myself and the rest of the class losing a few points on each lab for something that we missed or didn't know we had to do.
Great TA, good amount of time in lab, good amount of homework each week. Don't have any weaknesses.
Heavily TA dependent. I had an awful TA and had to do about 2-3 times as much work as my suitemates who were in the same course.
I felt like the exams, both the midterm and final, were a little too difficult. They seemed a little unfair.

I think the lab manuals were extremely helpful in allowing us to understand both what we were supposed to do and the underlying physical concepts. However, I would have appreciated more direction to be given for the quizzes.
I think the labs are quite boring and the grading is arbitrary. However, the topics of the lab did relate decently to the material taught in lecture.

Strength - very organized

Weakness - everybody is not graded by their ta.

The best part of it was the TA (Sheridan). The pairings of lab partners didn't really have a structure though; maybe it would be nice if we were assigned new people every time (this was the basic idea, but sometimes we ended up with the same people), or if we had the same ones every time so we could get to know them.

This course was ill-designed to prepare students for its assessments and it did not require us to do much actual creation of experimental techniques.  We usually followed explicit directions which somehow often still managed to be confusing enough to warrant requesting help from a TA.  At no time were we required to actually think about which experimental technique to employ or which experimental setup to follow in order to yield the best result.  As such, I felt quite unprepared for the final, which was significantly harder than the midterm and which asked us to do more of this type of experimentation than we had done all year.

I think the grading could be made more transparent, especially on the midterm. Points were taken off with no explanation and that made it difficult to see what I did wrong so I could improve for the final.

Like most other intro lab courses at Yale, this class is out to get you grade wise. You are given very loose guidelines for how to write lab reports and then you get points off for not including things you never knew you should have. The reports are graded out of 60 with 4 points allocated to insight, but it is wildly unclear what insight is or how to get all or even half of those points. The midterm and final are impossible. Literally NOBODY finished and I really just dont think that lab report or midterm/final grades are indicative do your understanding of lab techniques and data analysis.
there should be a life-science version of this class

This course does not align well with PHYS 170 so I feel like that was big weakness personally! Also, the experiments were somewhat boring and tedious. Moreover, I think there is a lot of variation between TAs; some TAs will make the class bearable while other will make this your least favorite class of the semester. Insight points will be the death of you.

It does try to teach physics concepts and integrates well with the university physics sequence. The labs are not very difficult and sometimes are eye opening, sometimes rather menial, but that seems unavoidable. Generally a decent course that does not cause undue stress and is generally provides a nice environment for making some new friends.

Strengths: mapped into lecture course material incredibly well, experiments good examples of material and often didnt feel useless
Weaknesses: a couple uselessly boring labs (coin flip, radiation), too much error calculation
The final exam was much harder than normal conducted experiments. So either class experiments need to be harder or the exam should be slightly leveled down.

Overall I thought that the course was structured very well. The course packets that we read before class every week were very on point and informative. You could tell that the instructors involved with organizing the course cared about everything running smoothly.
This course's only strength is the TAs, who clearly don't want to be there and are sympathetic to our similar plight.
I think the class was nicely structured but I think the final was too hard and it was weighted too much. Also the grading for the midterm and I'm assuming the final was too harsh.
Boring experiments highly dependent on TA for grading
Good survey of physics lab, there should be more background instruction
Some of the more complicated theoretical aspects could be more clarified as they were never really touched on.
It is good at applying the concepts we learned in physics class to real life.

Pretty straightforward lab that gives you all the resources and instructions that you need to complete the lab so there is not much guesswork or confusion in what you have to do, but there can be confusion in the principles of what you are trying to learn about but Prof. DeMille and my TA were very patient about explaining it (very patient, like saintly patient). There is a lot of writing with the lab manual which can make instructions kind of confusing and sometimes if you want to prepare for lab early, it's confusing because sometimes a new version will come up the day before the lab with instruction changes which was more annoying than anything. Sometimes tedious- only 3:30 pm hit, everyone was antsy.
you probably have to take it. less interesting than orgo and genchem lab, much more tedious
No one takes it because they want to. If you can find a way to skip it, do. Do a post-bacc, I dont know.
Nope. It sucked and anyone taking it has to.
Yes, if they are interested in seeing physical properties play out.
No - its miserable
No, unless you have to do it.
Yes, lecture covers the same topics but I suppose there's something novel about taking these measurements yourself in lab.
I would recommend this course only if you absolutely require it, for example as a pre-med or for your major.
I do, but the final and the midterm needs to be fixed.
I would only recommend this course if it is required, because I feel like I could have spent my time learning more effectively in another course and I didn't really get that much out of this.
No; not a lot of this course was enjoyable or fun to learn or challenging in a good way

I would only recommend taking this course if it is necessary for your major/ pre-med requirements. Otherwise, it will not really teach you anything that you can't get out of a statistics course or any other introductory lab course.
Course is not challenging. Very straightforward and one-dimensional course. Recommend course.
I would recommend this course, definitely more enjoyable than general Chem Lab, but chances are you are taking these labs for your major anyways.
Yes, I'd recommend the course to any future students looking to pursue a degree and/or career in the physical sciences.
I'd only recommend it if you have to take it or if you're in a physics lecture and are looking to improve your knowledge

If you're considering taking this course, it must be a requirement, so you're going to take it. It's not a bad time, and Prof. Baker is especially great, but the class experience is extremely dependent on your TF. It can become tedious and boring, but the work is not difficult, which lets you focus on the concepts more closely.
If you need it!
Yep! Especially if it's required.
Yes, if you need to take it
A required class for many people. The lab reports are straightforward, so there is not much work overall. The final was a bit challenging because of the timing.
Honestly a bit painful. The experiments were way too long and an utter waste of time.
Yes! I found it very helpful for some topics covered in Physics 180.
No, but you probably have to take it. A lot of work (mostly just time) for half a credit...

Absolutely not. The course is incredibly boring and should be only taken if needed for a requirement. Grading is arbitrary and depends on the TA, so some people find this class super easy and others get penalized for tiny errors. Most concepts are not explained well and then assessed rigorously. The final and midterm are really poorly set up. They are a huge time crunch but not actually that technically difficult, so you can get a really poor grade while knowing the material well if you make a tiny mistake and have to redo anything. The saving grace is that this class only takes about 3 hours in class per week and maybe an hour and a half outside of class each week to write the report.
I personally would not recommend this course to another student. Honestly speaking, perhaps the least enjoyable lab I've taken at Yale.
Not unless it was required for a major, it wasn't gripping enough to be interesting to everyone.
Only if you want to perform introductory physics experiments. It was not particularly stimulating for me.
Not really, it kinda sucks. Lab reports are graded very pickily and things are very unclear, such as grading and the lab manuals.
No unless it is a requirement
Only if you need it
Yes. You learn how to use LoggerPro, which is an infinitely helpful tool. Also, it isn't too too much work, so you can handle it.
I would recommend this class. It's straightforward and the best lab class I have taken so far at Yale.
Sure!
I would not recommend this course unless it is required.

If you're not going to medical school, I'd advise not taking the course. While I know it can be hard to set up interesting experiments, I just never felt intellectually engaged and would always one off reports because I could get a 59 or 60 on them.
Very subjective to who you get as a TA.  Everyone hates it. I liked it but the grading made me hate it
I would only recommend this course if you have to take it. Otherwise, it is a waste of time.
I would recommend this course if you really enjoy physics and are looking for a half-credit laboratory course on physics.

No. Your experience really depends on your TA, and I had a really bad one  even if you have a good TA, the course is just busywork and the labs don't really teach you much besides how to use LoggerPro (somewhat).
Don't take it unless you have to. It's the worst three hours of your week if you do take it, guaranteed.
If its required
Very good course.
No, unless your major requires it, the course is not rewarding or enjoyable.
Absolutely not, unless required for your major/premed.

Ewww. Labs barely taught me anything (with the exception of the torque lab with gyroscopes and bicycle wheels). Labs were also super boring and often felt pointless (rolling a dice hundreds of times for a lab about uncertainties? Waiting an hour to measure radioactive emissions from various materials? yes, these were actual labs). Midterm and final were super hard. The only redeeming thing about this lab is that the lab reports are significantly less work then gen chem lab.
Only take if you're pre-med.
Only if a physics lab is needed, as in for pre-med, for example.
You're taking this because you have to. It's a terrible class but you'll get through it.
I would not recommend this class to another student.
Only if you have to. Unnecessarily time consuming and not intellectually rewarding.
eh. take it if you have to. it feels like a gut until the practical hits you.
You have to take it most likely for your major or pre-med, but just be warned that you will have to pay attention to detail to get a good grade.
You probably have to take it for your major, but it is a solid course.  Not too much super good or bad about it.
Yuh
No, while some of the experiments are interesting, this course should only be taken if required.
No. Only take if you have to.
I would recommend it because many of the lab experiments were enjoyable and it was great  to work in a lab setting.
I would recommend the lab experience for those taking an introductory physics lecture.
I would recommend it if is required for major/pre-med track.

If you have to take it, then take it. It's not the worst thing in the world--in fact, the hardest parts are midterms and finals. Lab reports are simple and have relatively straightforward guidelines. Just gear up for the exams and do well on the lab reports! Also, make sure to meet with someone to explain topics you don't get because the class expects a rather in-depth understanding of the topics even though they don't give you any information.
It is mandatory for most students taking the course.

Do not take this class unless you need to. Unlike other lab classes, it does not provide much extension to lecture. Additionally, grading is harsh and you'll lose points for silly reasons. The quizzes were unnecessary and went beyond just checking if you had read the procedure.

Sure; it's good for reinforcing concepts from physics lecture (if you're taking PHYS 180; PHYS 170 doesn't connect as well, but if you're doing 170 you're probably pre-med and have to take this lab anyway)
Don't take this class unless you have to.
No, not unless you need it to fulfill a major or pre-med requirement.
Only take it if your major requires it.
Not unless you need to take it for your major or for a prerequisite. Super doable, not very hard but not very engaging either

I would definitely recommend this course to any student taking a Physics course at Yale. It definitely helped me understand the more confusing concepts we would only work out in equation during class time.
No. Unless you know a TA who will give you 60/60 on every lab, the course does not teach much about physics.

Personally, I felt that the final was not a fair representative of the labs that was covered throughout the semester. It didn't match closely with what was taught in the physics course yet the labs assume knowledge of physics concepts.
If you're pre-med, you probably have to take this course. Most of it is fine if you have a good TF, but the final exam is kind of absurd, so just watch out for that.
Only if you have to take it or really like doing, somewhat boring experiments.
Not if they don't have to take it for their major or pre-med.
I would not recommend this course to another student because many of the labs seemed pointless/boring, but most likely you are taking this because you have no choice.
Not really, unless you need it for a requirement. You just won't learn that much from this class.

Only if you need to take the lab. There were a couple of interesting things we saw/learned in the course, but no one wants to spend hours in a lab doing something they aren't really interested in. It's not a bad class, but it isn't fun.
If you gotta do it, you gotta do it.
This is probably a requirement. It's not awful, but I did not enjoy it.

No, but you probably have to take it. As a whole, the class wasn't terrible: the weekly workload wasn't bad and most labs were painless and got out early. I just don't feel like I learned much, mostly I just learned about uncertainties which feel a little pointless outside of the context of physics lab. The insight points that we were asked to include in each lab report also seemed unnecessary and were arbitrarily graded. Also, the midterm and final brought an unnecessary amount of stress. For context, I was taking a full STEM courseload this semester, and physics lab was my most stressful final. That shouldn't be the case.
Pretty much required for lots of stuff.
Not necessarily; if they did not need a physics lab credit then I would not recommend this course
Take it only if you have to.
Only take if you have to
Yes, the course isn't too difficult, so it's an easy way to get the half credit.
No.
Not unless you are required to take it
I would only recommend this course to students who needed to take an introductory physics lab.
no
if you have to!
Only take this course if you have to.
only take it if you have to, you will learn nothing

Just ... take it if you have to. Make sure you like your TA, because that can make or break how miserable of an experience this class was. There was one professor who would wander around and she was absolutely amazing, but my TA made it that much more of a struggle. I don't know why I'm bothering to review this class; if you're taking it, it's because you have to be here.
Yes, if needed for major

To be honest, only if the student has to. I thought the exams were quite a bit more difficult than the laboratories themselves, and I never felt particularly prepared before an exam despite my best efforts to study. I actually think the exam questions were pretty good in that they really forced you to think deeply about the concepts emphasized in the class, but I feel like we didn't have enough practice questions similar to the exams to really reinforce the ideas that had been introduced to us. The labs themselves were too easy to really allow students to learn new concepts.
I would recommend it if you have to take it.
Yes, great lab if they are interested in physics.
Well, you probably have to take it, but no, I would not recommend it. Heavily TA dependent. I had an awful TA and had to do about 2-3 times as much work as my suitemates who were in the same course.
I would take this lab if you need it!
No. It is boring, a waste of time, and you do not gain anything from it. However, it is a requirement for many majors.

Yes - it helped me gain a better understanding of topics learned in class.
I would only recommend this course if it is absolutely necessary for the student to complete their major.
NO unless you need it :(
no, unless you have to
I wouldn't recommend but you and I both know that if you're shopping this class you don't have that luxury. Bear through it; the lab reports are doable you will just hate the time you are there!

Not really, youre most likely going to take this out of necessity. It isnt painful but isnt often enjoyable. Does the classic lab thing of being more work than a half credit class probably should be, but when taking it out of necessity the half credit is appreciable as having less impact to your grade (if youre thinking about grad/med school)
This course is largely a requirement. If you dont have to, no real need to take it but if you do pretty fun.
It was interesting to see physics in action, but the final was a bit wrecking
Only if you need it for a requirement or if you have some sort of undying interest for physics lab.

This course is not really about physics, and the labs only demonstrate the most basic of physics concepts (gravity makes things fall!). It's well organized and fairly well taught, but the content is boring and not useful.

This is usually a required course. It evokes the same combination of boredom and rage as trying to communicate with Yale Health, driving across the Midwest in the winter, or making pasta for ten people by hand without a machine. If Phys 165L was a mode of transportation, it would be Spirit Airlines/Ryanair. The labs, which are seemingly graded by a random number generator, are designed to be so long and demoralizing that you leave every day with a renewed hatred of the sciences. If I was an unethical FBI interrogator, I would force suspects to do the lab where you flip a coin 100 times (and perform meaningless, opaque calculations on the results) over and over until they confessed. The final and midterm are barely related to the actual course material, impossible to study for, and could either be very difficult or very easy. Taking these exams is like appearing on a petty physics-themed version of Chopped/Iron Chef, which should not determine 40% of your final grade. The only good thing about this course is that everyone else in it hates it as well, which creates a camaraderie (except for the hyper-competitive premed snakes, who make up a significant portion of the class) not often seen in Yale courses. Every week, I would walk up science hill, inevitably in the cold and rain, wondering why I had been cursed with this academic requirement. Entering SPL, I would run into all the other students who were waiting for the classroom to open while rage-eating a mediocre quest bar from KBT. The mood in the hallway before the rooms open is very negative--I saw people crying there multiple times and didn't question it at all because this is a normal consequence of Phys 165L (or having to be on science hill for any reason, for that matter). Then, I would take the prelab quiz, which is usually very easy but has little relation to the lab itself. After three hours (never less, maybe more if I was unlucky) of futile physics experiments and arcane uncertainty calculations, I would be finally freed from the evil clutches of LoggerPro, a computer program used in all the labs which was probably last updated before my birth and is less functional than a humanities major's CS50 project. Dehydrated and demoralized, I would descend science hill, thankful that I had survived that week's iteration of Phys 165L. Over the next week, I would write a lab report on my results, which usually took an hour or two at most but had to be single-spaced  (at least the required font wasn't Wingdings, which seemed likely given the absurdity of this class). 
Here is a short list of things I would rather do than take this class, so you can further grasp its nature:
-eat at saybrook every meal for an entire semester
-break my hand again
-clean up the floor at Toads
-become a froco and stand duty for all 24 hours before & during spring fling
If you are not required to take this course but are still planning to, this reviewer is here to tell you that there are healthier and more fun ways to explore your masochistic needs.
I would recommend this course if you have to take it. If you don't it is a bit boring.
No
Only if you need to take it. It's rather boring
Yes, if you have to take it.

I would if you need to take it, it's not a bad lab at all - just sometimes tedious and sometimes data collection can make your eyes hurt and sometimes you will feel like walking out, but it's really not that bad. I had a cool and patient TA so he was really helpful in answering questions whenever.
